text: One of the prominent findings of this work is the need of interpretable AI systems.

text: Therefore, we also posit that future work should delve deeper into what types of explanations the general public expects from AI systems.
label: Future Work

text: Our study indicates these practices might not need to focus on compensating those harmed by these systems given the low attribution of liability to all agents.
label: Future Work

text: Future research can address which functions of responsibility attribution would satisfy this public attribution of backward-looking responsibilities to AI systems.
label: Future Work

text: Future studies can also address scenarios in which blame could be attributed to a higher degree, e.g., those with life-or-death consequences, such as self-driving vehicles and AI medical advisors.
label: Future Work

text: Psychological evidence further suggests that humans are innate retributivists [17].
label: Future Work
section: 5 DISCUSSION 5.4 AI and Human Agents Are Similarly Responsible for Consequences

text: However, future studies on similar topics should also consider scenarios in which AI systems and their human supervisors disagree.
label: Future Work

text: In our case study, human-AI collaborations are such that there exists an AI-in-theloop; future work should address other collaboration variations, such as human-in-the-loop, i.e., humans assisting machines.
label: Future Work

text: We recognize that other meanings of responsibility could be further considered, such as virtue-based notions where one might call an entity responsible in that it prescribes an evaluation of ones traits and dispositions [87, 94].
label: Future Work

text: Nevertheless, our research has found key clusters of responsibility notions concerning AI and human agents, opening further research directions.
label: Future Work

text: The phrasing column indicates how statements were phrased depending on which function of the bail decision they stressed: preventing further offenses (Further Offense) or protecting the defendants rights (Rights).
label: Future Work

text: Our primary goal was to examine how people attribute responsibility to human and AI agents in high-stakes scenarios.
label: Objective
section: 4 RESULTS 4.2 Responsibility Assignment to AI and Humans

text: 2 These statements aimed to capture different notions of responsibility (see Table 2 in the Appendix for the complete list).
label: Objective

text: The current study contributes by addressing the public perception of algorithmic decision-making through the lens of moral responsibility.
label: Objective
section: 2 BACKGROUND 2.3 Responsibility, Fairness, Trust in HCI Literature

text: This paper discussed the responsibility gap posed by the deployment of autonomous AI systems [68] and conducted a survey study to understand how differently people attribute responsibility to AI and humans.
label: Objective

text: We employed a factorial survey design [107] and showed participants eight vignettes that described a defendant from the ProPublica dataset, information about who the advisor was (i.e., an AI program or a human judge), which advice they gave, what the judges final decision was, and whether the defendant committed a new crime within the next two years (i.e., re-offended).
label: Method

text: To quantify the difference, we used a multivariate linear mixed model that included a random-effects term to control for each participant.
label: Method
section: 4 RESULTS 4.2 Responsibility Assignment to AI and Humans

text: After each interview, we iteratively refined our survey instrument based on the respondents feedback.
label: Method
